description: Triangle in which n-th row lists all primitive roots modulo the n-th prime.
comments: Number of terms per row is given by A008330. For example, A008330(10) = 12 and the 12 primitive roots associated with prime number 29 are 2,3,8,10,11,14,15,18,19,21,26,27. - _Alford Arnold_, Aug 22 2004
references: R. Osborn, Tables of All Primitive Roots of Odd Primes Less Than 1000, Univ. Texas Press, 1961.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..9076 (first 100 rows)
C. W. Curtis, Pioneers of Representation Theory, Amer. Math. Soc., 1999; see p. 3.

Wilson v_, Dec 17 2005 *)primRoots[p_] := (g = PrimitiveRoot[p]; goodOddIntegers = Select[Range[1, p-1, 2], CoprimeQ[#, p-1]&]; allPrimRoots = PowerMod[g, #, p]& /@ goodOddIntegers; Sort[allPrimRoots]); primRoots /@ Prime[Range[50]] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 12 2014, after _Peter Luschny_ *)roots[n_] := PrimitiveRootList[Prime[n]]; Array[roots, 50] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 01 2016 *)

Adams-Watters_, Jan 22 2012(Sage) # From Minh Van Nguyen, Functional Programming for Mathematicians, Tutorial at sagemath.org.def primroots(p):    g = primitive_root(p)    znorder = p - 1    is_coprime = lambda x: gcd(x, znorder) == 1    good_odd_integers = filter(is_coprime, [1..p-1, step=2])    all_primroots = [power_mod(g, k, p) for k in good_odd_integers]    all_primroots.sort()    return all_primrootsfor p in primes(1, 50) : print primroots(p) # _Peter Luschny_, Jun 08 2011
